Introduction
The concept of conditional probability is central to probability theory and excellent treatment of it can be found in many books. My aim with this blog post is to consolidate in one place some ideas around it which helped me form a better intuition. These ideas will be useful if you have already been exposed to this concept from a textbook and just want one more person's ramblings about it.
I will start by defining conditional expectation and stating some of its properties. It will be a grave injustice to claim my discussion of it is complete since I don't even prove its existence; this section exists solely for establishing notation. I will then spend some time discussing conditional probability, relating it to the traditional notion of
P(A∣B)=P(A∩B)P(B).\mathbb{P}(A \mid B) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(A \cap B)}{\mathbb{P}(B)}.P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A∩B)​.
These discussions will naturally lead to the notions of regular conditional probability and regular conditional distribution which I discuss next.
Conditional Expectation
Recall the concept of conditional expectation.
Theorem 1: Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space, and XXX﻿ a random variable with E(∣X∣)<∞.\mathbb{E}(|X|) < \infty.E(∣X∣)<∞.﻿ Let G\mathcal{G}G﻿ be a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of F.\mathcal{F}.F.﻿ Then there exists a random variable YYY﻿ such that
YYY﻿ is G\mathcal{G}G﻿-measurable,
E(∣Y∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|Y|) < \inftyE(∣Y∣)<∞﻿, and
∫GY dP=∫GX dP\int_G Y \,\mathrm{d}\mathbb{P} = \int_G X \,\mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}∫G​YdP=∫G​XdP﻿ for every G∈G.G \in \mathcal{G}.G∈G.﻿
Remarks:
It is easy to see from the π−λ\pi-\lambdaπ−λ﻿ theorem that the last condition can be relaxed such that ∫GY dP=∫GX dP\int_G Y \,\mathrm{d}\mathbb{P} = \int_G X \,\mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}∫G​YdP=∫G​XdP﻿ for every GGG﻿ in some π\piπ﻿-system which contains Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ and generates G.\mathcal{G}.G.﻿
If Y′Y'Y′﻿ is another random variable with the three properties above then Y′=YY' = YY′=Y﻿ a.s.. Therefore, YYY﻿ in the theorem above is called a version of the conditional expectation. The notation E ⁣(X ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(X∣G)﻿ is used to denote this unique (up to a.e. equivalence) random variable.
The proof of this standard theorem can be found in any probability textbook. See [1,2] for example.
Definition 1: In the setting of Theorem 1, if ZZZ﻿ is a random variable, we write E ⁣(X ∣ Z)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, Z \right)E(X∣Z)﻿ for E ⁣(X ∣ σ(Z)).\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \sigma(Z) \right).E(X∣σ(Z)).﻿
The fact that conditional expectation is defined as a random variable might come as a surprise, but the correspondence with the traditional usage of conditional expectation as a number becomes clear once you realize that here we are conditioning on a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra instead of a single event (we haven’t defined what conditioning on an event means, but think of the intuitive meaning for now). For example, consider the life expectancy of a new born baby conditioned on sex. This is a random variable that takes one value for males and another value for females.
Properties of conditional expectation
For completeness I state some useful properties of conditional expectation. You can find the proofs in [1,2] for example. Most of them are parallels to the well-known properties of (unconditional) expectation. Assume that all the XXX﻿'s satisfy E(∣X∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|X|) < \inftyE(∣X∣)<∞﻿ and let G,H\mathcal{G}, \mathcal{H}G,H﻿ be sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebras of F.\mathcal{F}.F.﻿
[Linearity] E ⁣(a1X1+a2X2 ∣ G)=a1E ⁣(X1 ∣ G)+a2E ⁣(X2 ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. a_1 X_1 + a_2 X_2\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = a_1 \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X_1\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) + a_2 \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X_2\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(a1​X1​+a2​X2​∣G)=a1​E(X1​∣G)+a2​E(X2​∣G)﻿ a.s. for real numbers a1a_1a1​﻿ and a2.a_2.a2​.﻿
[Positivity] If X≥0X \ge 0X≥0﻿, then E ⁣(X ∣ G)≥0\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \ge 0E(X∣G)≥0﻿ a.s..
[Monotone convergence theorem for conditional expectation] If E(∣Y∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|Y|) < \inftyE(∣Y∣)<∞﻿ and Y≤Xn↑XY \le X_n \uparrow XY≤Xn​↑X﻿ a.s., then E ⁣(Xn ∣ G)↑E ⁣(X ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \uparrow \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(Xn​∣G)↑E(X∣G)﻿ a.s..
[Fatou's lemma for conditional expectation] If E(∣Y∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|Y|) < \inftyE(∣Y∣)<∞﻿ and Y≤XnY \le X_nY≤Xn​﻿ for all n≥1n \ge 1n≥1﻿ a.s., then E ⁣(lim inf⁡n→∞Xn ∣ G)≤lim inf⁡n→∞E ⁣(Xn ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. \liminf_{n \to \infty} X_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \le \liminf_{n \to \infty}\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(liminfn→∞​Xn​∣G)≤liminfn→∞​E(Xn​∣G)﻿ a.s..
[Dominated convergence theorem for conditional expectation] If ∣Xn∣≤∣Y∣|X_n| \le |Y|∣Xn​∣≤∣Y∣﻿ for all n≥1n \ge 1n≥1﻿, E(∣Y∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|Y|) < \inftyE(∣Y∣)<∞﻿, and Xn→XX_n \to XXn​→X﻿ a.s., then E ⁣(Xn ∣ G)→E ⁣(X ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \to \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(Xn​∣G)→E(X∣G)﻿ a.s..
[Tower property] If H⊆G\mathcal{H} \subseteq \mathcal{G}H⊆G﻿, then E ⁣(E ⁣(X ∣ G) ∣ H)=E ⁣(E ⁣(X ∣ H) ∣ G)=E ⁣(X ∣ H)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{H}\right) = \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{H}\right)\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)=\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{H}\right)E(E(X∣G)∣H)=E(E(X∣H)∣G)=E(X∣H)﻿ a.s.
[Taking out what's known] If YYY﻿ is G\mathcal{G}G﻿-measurable and bounded, then
E ⁣(YX ∣ G)=YE ⁣(X ∣ G) a.s..(1)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. YX\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = Y \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \text{ a.s..} \tag{1}E(YX∣G)=YE(X∣G) a.s..(1)
If p>1p > 1p>1﻿, 1/p+1/q=11/p + 1/q = 11/p+1/q=1﻿, X∈Lp(Ω,F,P)X \in L^p(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})X∈Lp(Ω,F,P)﻿ and Y∈Lq(Ω,G,P)Y \in L^q(\Omega, \mathcal{G}, \mathbb{P})Y∈Lq(Ω,G,P)﻿, then (1)(1)(1)﻿ again holds. If XXX﻿ is a nonnegative F\mathcal{F}F﻿-measurable random variable, YYY﻿ is a nonnegative G\mathcal{G}G﻿-measurable random variable, E(X)<∞\mathbb{E}(X) < \inftyE(X)<∞﻿ and E(XY)<∞\mathbb{E}(XY) < \inftyE(XY)<∞﻿, then also (1)(1)(1)﻿ holds.
[Role of independence] If H\mathcal{H}H﻿ is independent of σ(σ(X)∪G)\sigma(\sigma(X) \cup \mathcal{G})σ(σ(X)∪G)﻿, then E ⁣(X ∣ σ(G∪H))=E ⁣(X ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \sigma(\mathcal{G} \cup \mathcal H)\right) = \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(X∣σ(G∪H))=E(X∣G)﻿ a.s.. In particular, if XXX﻿ is independent of H\mathcal{H}H﻿, then E ⁣(X ∣ H)=E(X)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{H}\right) = \mathbb{E}(X)E(X∣H)=E(X)﻿ a.s..
Conditional Probability
Definition 2: In the setting of Theorem 1, if A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F﻿, we let P ⁣(A ∣ G)\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)P(A∣G)﻿ to mean E ⁣(1A ∣ G)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. \mathbf{1}_A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)E(1A​∣G)﻿ and call it the conditional probability of AAA﻿ given G\mathcal{G}G﻿. Here 1A\mathbf{1}_A1A​﻿ is the indicator random variable. If B∈FB \in \mathcal{F}B∈F﻿, we let P ⁣(A ∣ B)\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, B\right)P(A∣B)﻿ to mean E ⁣(1A ∣ 1B).\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. \mathbf{1}_A\,\right\vert\, \mathbf{1}_B\right).E(1A​∣1B​).﻿
Just like conditional expectation, conditional probability, as defined above, is a random variable! Unlike conditional expectation this isn't very palpable and deserves more rumination [3]. We have our probability space (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ and let A,B∈FA,B \in \mathcal{F}A,B∈F﻿ be such that P(B)≠0\mathbb{P}(B) \neq 0P(B)=0﻿ and P(Bc)≠0.\mathbb{P}(B^\mathsf{c}) \neq 0.P(Bc)=0.﻿ Then our traditional notion of conditional probability tells us that the conditional probability of AAA﻿ given BBB﻿ is defined by
PB(A)=P(A∩B)P(B).\mathbb{P}_B(A) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(A \cap B)}{\mathbb{P}(B)}.PB​(A)=P(B)P(A∩B)​.
Let us investigate how PB(A)\mathbb{P}_B(A)PB​(A)﻿ depends on B.B.B.﻿ To this end, introduce the discrete measurable space (Λ,2Λ)(\Lambda, 2^\Lambda)(Λ,2Λ)﻿ with Λ={λ1,λ2}\Lambda = \{\lambda_1, \lambda_2\}Λ={λ1​,λ2​}﻿, and a measurable mapping T ⁣:Ω→ΛT \colon \Omega \to \LambdaT:Ω→Λ﻿ such that
T(ω)={λ1 if ω∈Bλ2 if ω∈Bc.T(\omega) = \begin{cases} \lambda_1 & \text{ if } \omega \in B \\ \lambda_2 & \text{ if } \omega \in B^\mathsf{c}. \end{cases}T(ω)={λ1​λ2​​ if ω∈B if ω∈Bc.​
Define the two measures νA\nu_AνA​﻿ and ν\nuν﻿ on (Λ,2Λ)(\Lambda, 2^\Lambda)(Λ,2Λ)﻿ as follows for any E⊆ΛE \subseteq \LambdaE⊆Λ﻿,
νA(E)=P(A∩T−1(E))ν(E)=P(T−1(E)).\begin{align*} \nu_A(E) &= \mathbb{P}(A \cap T^{-1}(E))\\ \nu(E) &= \mathbb{P}(T^{-1}(E)). \end{align*}νA​(E)ν(E)​=P(A∩T−1(E))=P(T−1(E)).​
Then it is easy to see that
PB(A)=νA({λ1})ν({λ1})PBc(A)=νA({λ2})ν({λ2}).\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}_B(A) &= \frac{\nu_A(\{\lambda_1\})}{\nu(\{\lambda_1\})} \\ \mathbb{P}_{B^\mathsf{c}}(A) &= \frac{\nu_A(\{\lambda_2\})}{\nu(\{\lambda_2\})}. \end{align*}PB​(A)PBc​(A)​=ν({λ1​})νA​({λ1​})​=ν({λ2​})νA​({λ2​})​.​
In other words conditional probability may be viewed as a measurable function on Λ.\Lambda.Λ.﻿
This can easily be generalized to any finite setting as follows. Let {A1,…,An}⊆F\{A_1, \ldots, A_n\} \subseteq \mathcal{F}{A1​,…,An​}⊆F﻿ be a partition of Ω\OmegaΩ﻿, i.e., Ai∩Aj=∅A_i \cap A_j = \varnothingAi​∩Aj​=∅﻿ for i≠ji \neq ji=j﻿ and ⋃iAi=Ω.\bigcup_i A_i = \Omega.⋃i​Ai​=Ω.﻿ Introduce the discrete measurable space (Λ,2Λ)(\Lambda, 2^\Lambda)(Λ,2Λ)﻿ with Λ={λ1,…,λn}.\Lambda = \{\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n\}.Λ={λ1​,…,λn​}.﻿ Define a measurable mapping T ⁣:Ω→ΛT \colon \Omega \to \LambdaT:Ω→Λ﻿ such that T(ω)=λiT(\omega) = \lambda_iT(ω)=λi​﻿ whenever ω∈Ai.\omega \in A_i.ω∈Ai​.﻿ Define the measures νA1,…,νAn,ν\nu_{A_1}, \ldots, \nu_{A_n}, \nuνA1​​,…,νAn​​,ν﻿ on (Λ,2Λ)(\Lambda, 2^\Lambda)(Λ,2Λ)﻿ as follows for any E⊆ΛE \subseteq \LambdaE⊆Λ﻿,
νAi(E)=P(Ai∩T−1(E))for all i=1,…,nν(E)=P(T−1(E)).\begin{align*} \nu_{A_i}(E) &= \mathbb{P}(A_i \cap T^{-1}(E))\quad \text{for all } i = 1, \ldots, n\\ \nu(E) &= \mathbb{P}(T^{-1}(E)). \end{align*}νAi​​(E)ν(E)​=P(Ai​∩T−1(E))for all i=1,…,n=P(T−1(E)).​
Then once again we have for any A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F﻿,
PAi(A)=P(A∩Ai)P(Ai)=νAi({λi})ν({λi})for all i=1,…,n.\mathbb{P}_{A_i}(A) = \frac{\mathbb{P}(A \cap A_i)}{\mathbb{P}(A_i)} = \frac{\nu_{A_i}(\{\lambda_i\})}{\nu(\{\lambda_i\})} \quad \text{for all } i = 1, \ldots, n.PAi​​(A)=P(Ai​)P(A∩Ai​)​=ν({λi​})νAi​​({λi​})​for all i=1,…,n.
These considerations are what motivated the definition of conditional probability in general cases as you see in Definition 2. If TTT﻿ is any measurable mapping from (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ into an arbitrary measurable space (Λ,L)(\Lambda, \mathcal{L})(Λ,L)﻿, and if we write νA(E)=P(A∩T−1(E))\nu_A(E) = \mathbb{P}(A \cap T^{-1}(E))νA​(E)=P(A∩T−1(E))﻿ where A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F﻿ and E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L﻿, then it is clear that νE\nu_EνE​﻿ and P∘T−1\mathbb{P} \circ T^{-1}P∘T−1﻿ are measures on L\mathcal{L}L﻿ such that νA≪P∘T−1.\nu_A \ll \mathbb{P} \circ T^{-1}.νA​≪P∘T−1.﻿ Radon-Nikodym theorem now implies that there exists an P∘T−1\mathbb{P} \circ T^{-1}P∘T−1﻿-integrable function pAp_ApA​﻿, unique upto P∘T−1\mathbb{P} \circ T^{-1}P∘T−1﻿-a.e., such that
P(A∩T−1(E))=∫EpA(λ)  (P∘T−1)(dλ)for all E∈L.\mathbb{P}(A \cap T^{-1}(E)) = \int_E p_A(\lambda) \; (\mathbb{P} \circ T^{-1})(\mathrm{d} \lambda) \quad \text{for all } E \in \mathcal{L}.P(A∩T−1(E))=∫E​pA​(λ)(P∘T−1)(dλ)for all E∈L.
We anoint pA(λ)p_A(\lambda)pA​(λ)﻿ as the conditional probability of AAA﻿ given λ∈Λ\lambda \in \Lambdaλ∈Λ﻿ or the conditional probability of AAA﻿ given that T(ω)=λ.T(\omega) = \lambda.T(ω)=λ.﻿ Note that here we are conditioning on a measurable mapping TTT﻿ instead of a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, but this notion is related to conditioning on σ(T)\sigma(T)σ(T)﻿ as will become clear ahead. Keep this "rumination" in mind when we discuss regular conditional distribution later.
Let's look at our definition of conditional probability from the other direction and show that P(A∣B)\mathbb{P}(A \mid B)P(A∣B)﻿ as defined in Definition 2 conforms to our traditional usage. To start, note that σ(1B)={∅,B,Bc,Ω}\sigma(\mathbf{1}_B) =\{\varnothing, B, B^\mathsf{c}, \Omega\}σ(1B​)={∅,B,Bc,Ω}﻿, and since P(A∣B)\mathbb{P}(A \mid B)P(A∣B)﻿ is σ(1B)\sigma(\mathbf{1}_B)σ(1B​)﻿-measurable, it must be constant on each of the sets B,BcB, B^\mathsf{c}B,Bc﻿, thereby necessitating
P(A∣B)(ω)={P(A∩B)P(B) if ω∈BP(A∩Bc)P(Bc) if ω∈Bc\mathbb{P}(A \mid B)(\omega) = \begin{cases} \frac{\mathbb{P}(A \cap B)}{\mathbb{P}(B)} & \text{ if } \omega \in B \\ \frac{\mathbb{P}(A \cap B^\mathsf{c})}{\mathbb{P}(B^\mathsf{c})} & \text{ if } \omega \in B^\mathsf{c} \end{cases}P(A∣B)(ω)={P(B)P(A∩B)​P(Bc)P(A∩Bc)​​ if ω∈B if ω∈Bc​
because of property 3. of Theorem 1 by taking GGG﻿ to be BBB﻿ and Bc.B^\mathsf{c}.Bc.﻿ Of course, if any of the sets BBB﻿ or BcB^\mathsf{c}Bc﻿ is of measure 000﻿, then you can take the corresponding value for P(A∣B)(ω)\mathbb{P}(A \mid B)(\omega)P(A∣B)(ω)﻿ to be anything in [0,1][0,1][0,1]﻿ and it won't matter since the concept of conditional probability is defined only up to sets of measure 0.0.0.﻿
Properties of conditional probability
Positivity property (property 2. above) and monotone convergence property (property 3. above) of conditional expectation imply 0≤P ⁣(A ∣ G)≤10 \le\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \le 10≤P(A∣G)≤1﻿ a.s. for any A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F﻿, P ⁣(A ∣ G)=0\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = 0P(A∣G)=0﻿ a.s. if and only if P(A)=0\mathbb{P}(A) = 0P(A)=0﻿, and P ⁣(A ∣ G)=1\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = 1P(A∣G)=1﻿ a.s. if and only if P(A)=1.\mathbb{P}(A) = 1.P(A)=1.﻿
Let A1,A2,…∈FA_1, A_2, \ldots \in \mathcal{F}A1​,A2​,…∈F﻿ be a sequence of disjoint sets. By linearity (property 1. above) and monotone convergence theorem for conditional expectation, we see that
P ⁣(⋃nAn ∣ G)=∑nP ⁣(An ∣ G)a.s..(2)\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. \bigcup_n A_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = \sum_n \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \quad \text{a.s.}. \tag{2}P(n⋃​An​∣∣​G)=n∑​P(An​∣G)a.s..(2)
If An∈FA_n \in \mathcal{F}An​∈F﻿ for n≥1n \ge 1n≥1﻿ and lim⁡n→∞An=A\lim_{n \to \infty} A_n = Alimn→∞​An​=A﻿, then we also have lim⁡n→∞P ⁣(An ∣ G)=P ⁣(A ∣ G)\lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) = \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)limn→∞​P(An​∣G)=P(A∣G)﻿ a.s..
It seems very tempting from the foregoing discussion to claim that P ⁣(⋅ ∣ G)(ω)\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. \cdot\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega)P(⋅∣G)(ω)﻿ is a probability measure on F\mathcal{F}F﻿ for almost all ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿, but except for some nice spaces, which we will discuss below, this isn't true. Let us first try to see this intuitively [2]. Equation (2)(2)(2)﻿ holds for all ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿ EXCEPT for some null set which may well depend on the particular sequence {An}n∈N.\{A_n\}_{n \in \N}.{An​}n∈N​.﻿ It does NOT stipulate that there exists a fixed null set N∈FN \in \mathcal{F}N∈F﻿ such that
P ⁣(⋃nAn ∣ G)(ω)=∑nP ⁣(An ∣ G)(ω),ω∈Ω∖N\mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. \bigcup_n A_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega) = \sum_n \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A_n\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega), \quad \omega \in \Omega \setminus NP(n⋃​An​∣∣​G)(ω)=n∑​P(An​∣G)(ω),ω∈Ω∖N
for every disjoint sequence {An}n∈N⊆F.\{A_n\}_{n \in \N} \subseteq \mathcal{F}.{An​}n∈N​⊆F.﻿ Except in trivial cases, there are uncountably many disjoint sequences, and therefore we will need uncountable union of such null sets to be of measure 000﻿, which of course may not even be defined let alone be of measure 0.0.0.﻿ To further drive this point home you can take a look at an explicit example of how this can fail in an exercise in [3] on page 210.
Regular Conditional Probability
Motivated by our discussion above, we define regular conditional probability as follows.
Definition 3: Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space and G,H\mathcal{G}, \mathcal{H}G,H﻿ be sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebras of F.\mathcal{F}.F.﻿ A regular conditional probability on H\mathcal{H}H﻿ given G\mathcal{G}G﻿ is a function P(⋅,⋅) ⁣:Ω×H→[0,1]\mathbb{P}(\cdot, \cdot) \colon \Omega \times \mathcal{H} \to [0,1]P(⋅,⋅):Ω×H→[0,1]﻿ such that
for a.e. ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿, P(ω,⋅)\mathbb{P}(\omega, \cdot)P(ω,⋅)﻿ is a probability measure on H\mathcal{H}H﻿,
for each A∈HA \in \mathcal{H}A∈H﻿, P(⋅,A)\mathbb{P}(\cdot, A)P(⋅,A)﻿ is a G\mathcal{G}G﻿-measurable function on Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ coinciding with the conditional probability of AAA﻿ given G\mathcal{G}G﻿, i.e., P(⋅,A)=P ⁣(A ∣ G)\mathbb{P}(\cdot, A) = \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. A\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)P(⋅,A)=P(A∣G)﻿ a.s..
Let's show that this definition is not outrageous by showing that it agrees with our traditional notion of conditional pdf and conditional expectation. To that end, suppose that XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are random variables which have a joint probability density function fX,Y(x,y).f_{X,Y}(x,y).fX,Y​(x,y).﻿ This means that we are considering the probability space (R2,B(R2),P)(\R^2, \mathcal{B}(\R^2), \mathbb{P})(R2,B(R2),P)﻿ with XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ being the coordinate random variables, i.e. (x,y)↦x(x,y) \mapsto x(x,y)↦x﻿ and (x,y)↦y(x,y) \mapsto y(x,y)↦y﻿ respectively, and having an absolutely continuous distribution function FX,Y(x,y)F_{X,Y}(x,y)FX,Y​(x,y)﻿ such that
FX,Y(x,y)=∫−∞y∫−∞xfX,Y(s,t)  ds dt.F_{X,Y}(x,y) = \int_{-\infty}^y \int_{-\infty}^x f_{X,Y}(s,t) \; \mathrm{d} s \, \mathrm{d} t.FX,Y​(x,y)=∫−∞y​∫−∞x​fX,Y​(s,t)dsdt.

For the corresponding analysis for conditional expectation, let hhh﻿ be a Borel function on R2\R^2R2﻿ such that
E∣h(X,Y)∣=∫R∫R∣h(x,y)∣fX,Y(x,y) dx dy<∞.\mathbb{E}{|h(X,Y)|} = \int_\R \int_\R |h(x,y)| f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, \mathrm{d} x \, \mathrm{d} y < \infty.E∣h(X,Y)∣=∫R​∫R​∣h(x,y)∣fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy<∞.
Set
g(y)=∫Rh(s,y)fX∣Y(s∣y) ds.g(y) = \int_\R h(s, y) f_{X \mid Y}(s \mid y) \, \mathrm{d} s.g(y)=∫R​h(s,y)fX∣Y​(s∣y)ds.
g(y)g(y)g(y)﻿ is the traditional conditional density of h(X,Y)h(X, Y)h(X,Y)﻿ given Y=y.Y = y.Y=y.﻿ Then the claim is that
g(Y)=E ⁣(h(X,Y) ∣ σ(Y))a.s..g(Y) = \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. h(X,Y)\,\right\vert\, \sigma(Y)\right) \text{a.s.}.g(Y)=E(h(X,Y)∣σ(Y))a.s..
A typical element of σ(Y)\sigma(Y)σ(Y)﻿ has the form {ω∈R2 : Y(ω)∈B}\{\omega \in \R^2 \, : \, Y(\omega) \in B\}{ω∈R2:Y(ω)∈B}﻿, where B∈B(R).B \in \mathcal{B}(\R).B∈B(R).﻿ Hence, we must show that
L=E[h(X,Y)1B(Y)]=E[g(Y)1B(Y)]=R.L = \mathbb{E}\left[h(X,Y) \mathbf{1}_{B}(Y)\right] = \mathbb{E}\left[g(Y) \mathbf{1}_{B}(Y)\right] = R.L=E[h(X,Y)1B​(Y)]=E[g(Y)1B​(Y)]=R.
But we can write LLL﻿ and RRR﻿ as
L=∫∫h(x,y)1B(y)fX,Y(x,y) dx dyR=∫g(y)1B(y)fY(y) dy\begin{align*} L &= \int \int h(x,y) \mathbf{1}_{B}(y) f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, \mathrm{d} x \, \mathrm{d} y \\ R &= \int g(y) \mathbf{1}_{B}(y) f_Y(y) \, \mathrm{d} y \end{align*}LR​=∫∫h(x,y)1B​(y)fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy=∫g(y)1B​(y)fY​(y)dy​
and they are equal by Fubini's theorem.
In general, we have the following useful theorem (taken from [2]) which allows us to view conditional expectations as ordinary expectations relative to the measure induced by regular conditional probability.
Theorem 2: Consider the setting of Definition 3 and denote Pω(⋅)=P(ω,⋅).\mathbb{P}_\omega(\cdot) = \mathbb{P}(\omega, \cdot).Pω​(⋅)=P(ω,⋅).﻿ Let XXX﻿ be an H\mathcal{H}H﻿-measurable function with E(X)<∞.\mathbb{E}(X) < \infty.E(X)<∞.﻿ Then
E ⁣(X ∣ G)(ω)=∫ΩX dPωa.s..(3)\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. X\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega) = \int_\Omega X \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}_\omega \quad \text{a.s.}. \tag{3}E(X∣G)(ω)=∫Ω​XdPω​a.s..(3)
Proof:
Recall the monotone class theorem for functions:
Let H\mathscr{H}H﻿ be a family of nonnegative functions on Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ which contains all indicators of sets of some class H\mathcal{H}H﻿ of subsets of Ω.\Omega.Ω.﻿ If either (i) H\mathcal{H}H﻿ is a π\piπ﻿-class and H\mathscr{H}H﻿ is a λ\lambdaλ﻿-system, or (ii) H\mathcal{H}H﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra and H\mathscr{H}H﻿ is a monotone system, then H\mathscr{H}H﻿ contains all nonnegative σ(H)\sigma(\mathcal{H})σ(H)﻿-measurable functions.
By separate considerations of X+X^+X+﻿ and X−X^-X−﻿, it may be supposed that X≥0.X \ge 0.X≥0.﻿ Define
H={X : X≥0, X is H-measurable, and (3) holds for X}.\mathscr{H} = \{X \, : \, X \ge 0,\, X \text{ is } \mathcal{H} \text{-measurable, and (3) holds for } X\}.H={X:X≥0,X is H-measurable, and (3) holds for X}.
By the definition of regular conditional probability, 1A∈H\mathbf{1}_A \in \mathscr{H}1A​∈H﻿ for A∈H.A \in \mathcal{H}.A∈H.﻿ H\mathcal{H}H﻿ is already a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra. Let's show that H\mathscr{H}H﻿ is a monotone system.
If X1,X2∈HX_1, X_2 \in \mathscr{H}X1​,X2​∈H﻿ and c1,c2≥0c_1, c_2 \ge 0c1​,c2​≥0﻿, then c1X1+c2X2≥0c_1 X_1 + c_2 X_2 \ge 0c1​X1​+c2​X2​≥0﻿, c1X1+c2X2c_1 X_1 + c_2 X_2c1​X1​+c2​X2​﻿ is H\mathcal{H}H﻿-measurable and Equation (3)(3)(3)﻿ holds because of linearity of expectation and conditional expectation, and thus c1X1+c2X2∈H.c_1 X_1 + c_2 X_2 \in \mathscr{H}.c1​X1​+c2​X2​∈H.﻿ If {Xn}n∈N⊆H\{X_n\}_{n \in \N} \subseteq \mathscr{H}{Xn​}n∈N​⊆H﻿ such that Xn↑XX_n \uparrow XXn​↑X﻿, then X≥0X \ge 0X≥0﻿, XXX﻿ is H\mathcal{H}H﻿-measurable, and Equation (3)(3)(3)﻿ holds for XXX﻿ because of monotone convergence theorem for expectation and conditional expectation, and thus X∈H.X \in \mathscr{H}.X∈H.﻿ Therefore, by the monotone class theorem H\mathscr{H}H﻿ contains all nonnegative H\mathcal{H}H﻿-measurable functions. □\square□﻿
Regular Conditional Distribution
In some cases even the concept of regular conditional probability in inadequate, and that motivates the concept of regular conditional distributions.
Definition 4: Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space, G⊆F\mathcal{G} \subseteq \mathcal{F}G⊆F﻿ a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, (Λ,L)(\Lambda, \mathcal{L})(Λ,L)﻿ a measurable space, and T ⁣:Ω→ΛT \colon \Omega \to \LambdaT:Ω→Λ﻿ a measurable mapping. A regular conditional distribution for TTT﻿ given G\mathcal{G}G﻿ is a function PT ⁣:Ω×L→[0,1]\mathbb{P}_T \colon \Omega \times \mathcal{L} \to [0,1]PT​:Ω×L→[0,1]﻿ such that
for a.e. ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿, PT(ω,⋅)\mathbb{P}_T(\omega, \cdot)PT​(ω,⋅)﻿ is a probability measure on L\mathcal{L}L﻿,
for each A∈LA \in \mathcal{L}A∈L﻿, PT(⋅,A)\mathbb{P}_T(\cdot, A)PT​(⋅,A)﻿ is a G\mathcal{G}G﻿-measurable function on Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ coinciding with the conditional probability of T−1(A)T^{-1}(A)T−1(A)﻿ given G\mathcal{G}G﻿, i.e., PT(⋅,A)=P ⁣(T−1(A) ∣ G)\mathbb{P}_T(\cdot, A) = \mathbb{P}\!\left(\left. T^{-1}(A)\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)PT​(⋅,A)=P(T−1(A)∣∣​G)﻿ a.s..
It is clear that when Λ=Ω\Lambda = \OmegaΛ=Ω﻿, L=H⊆F\mathcal{L} = \mathcal{H} \subseteq \mathcal{F}L=H⊆F﻿ and TTT﻿ is the identity map, PT\mathbb{P}_TPT​﻿ is exactly the regular conditional probability as defined in Definition 3.
Now would be a good time to reread the first "rumination" in the section Conditional Probability and realize that the definition of regular conditional distribution is in fact well motivated.
A corresponding version of Theorem 2 exists, proof of which I'll leave as an easy exercise:
Theorem 3: In the setting of Definition 4, if PTω(A)=PT(ω,A)\mathbb{P}_T^\omega(A) = \mathbb{P}_T(\omega, A)PTω​(A)=PT​(ω,A)﻿ and h ⁣:Λ→Rh \colon \Lambda \to \Rh:Λ→R﻿ is a Borel function with E(∣h(T)∣)<∞\mathbb{E}(|h(T)|) < \inftyE(∣h(T)∣)<∞﻿, then
E ⁣(h(T) ∣ G)(ω)=∫Λh(λ) PTω(dλ).\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. h(T)\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega) = \int_\Lambda h(\lambda) \, \mathbb{P}_T^\omega(\mathrm{d}\lambda).E(h(T)∣G)(ω)=∫Λ​h(λ)PTω​(dλ).
To see the power of thinking about conditional probabilities like this, let's give an unbelievably short proof of conditional Hölder's inequality that I took from [2]. Contrast it with other proofs.
Theorem 4: If X,YX,YX,Y﻿ are random variables on (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P)﻿, G⊆F\mathcal{G} \subseteq \mathcal{F}G⊆F﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra, and 1<p<∞1 < p < \infty1<p<∞﻿, 1/p+1/q=11/p + 1/q = 11/p+1/q=1﻿, then
E ⁣(∣XY∣ ∣ G)≤[E ⁣(∣X∣p ∣ G)]1/p[E ⁣(∣Y∣q ∣ G)]1/q a.s..\mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |XY|\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right) \le \left[ \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |X|^p\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)\right]^{1/p}\left[ \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |Y|^q\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)\right]^{1/q} \text{ a.s.}.E(∣XY∣∣G)≤[E(∣X∣p∣G)]1/p[E(∣Y∣q∣G)]1/q a.s..
Proof:
For B∈B(R2)B \in \mathcal{B}(\R^2)B∈B(R2)﻿ and ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿, let PX,Yω(B)=PX,Y(ω,B)\mathbb{P}_{X,Y}^\omega(B) = \mathbb{P}_{X,Y}(\omega, B)PX,Yω​(B)=PX,Y​(ω,B)﻿ be the regular conditional distribution for (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y)﻿ given G.\mathcal{G}.G.﻿ Theorem 3 allows us to write
E ⁣(∣XY∣ ∣ G)(ω)=∫R2∣xy∣ PX,Yω(d(x,y))[E ⁣(∣X∣p ∣ G)]1/p(ω)=[∫R2∣x∣p PX,Yω(d(x,y))]1/p[E ⁣(∣Y∣q ∣ G)]1/q(ω)=[∫R2∣y∣q PX,Yω(d(x,y))]1/q.\begin{align*} \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |XY|\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)(\omega) &= \int_{\R^2} |x y| \,\mathbb{P}_{X,Y}^\omega(\mathrm{d} (x,y))\\ \left[ \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |X|^p\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)\right]^{1/p}(\omega) &= \left[ \int_{\R^2} |x|^p \, \mathbb{P}_{X,Y}^\omega(\mathrm{d} (x,y)) \right]^{1/p} \\ \left[ \mathbb{E}\!\left(\left. |Y|^q\,\right\vert\, \mathcal{G}\right)\right]^{1/q}(\omega) &= \left[ \int_{\R^2} |y|^q \, \mathbb{P}_{X,Y}^\omega(\mathrm{d} (x,y)) \right]^{1/q}. \end{align*}E(∣XY∣∣G)(ω)[E(∣X∣p∣G)]1/p(ω)[E(∣Y∣q∣G)]1/q(ω)​=∫R2​∣xy∣PX,Yω​(d(x,y))=[∫R2​∣x∣pPX,Yω​(d(x,y))]1/p=[∫R2​∣y∣qPX,Yω​(d(x,y))]1/q.​
And now our desired inequality follows immediately from the ordinary Hölder's inequality. □\square□﻿
Existence of Regular Conditional Distribution
Before we discuss their existence, let us define the concept of standard Borel space [6].
Definition 5: Let (X,X)(X, \mathcal{X})(X,X)﻿ and (Y,Y)(Y, \mathcal{Y})(Y,Y)﻿ be two measurable spaces. They are called isomorphic if there exists a bijection f ⁣:X→Yf \colon X \to Yf:X→Y﻿ such that fff﻿ and its inverse f−1f^{-1}f−1﻿ are both measurable. The function fff﻿ is called an isomorphism.
Definition 6: A measurable space (X,X)(X, \mathcal{X})(X,X)﻿ is called a standard Borel space if it satisfies any of the following equivalent conditions:
(X,X)(X, \mathcal{X})(X,X)﻿ is isomorphic to some compact metric space with the Borel σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra.
(X,X)(X, \mathcal{X})(X,X)﻿ is isomorphic to some Polish space (i.e., a separable complete metric space) with the Borel σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra.
(X,X)(X, \mathcal{X})(X,X)﻿ is isomorphic to some Borel subset of some Polish space with the Borel σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra.
As you can guess most spaces we deal with are standard Borel spaces. Durrett [5] calls these space nice since we already have too many things named after Borel. I am not sure I agree with his reasoning but I like Durrett's terminology.
The next two theorems show the existence of regular conditional distribution and are taken from [5, Section 4.1.3]. See also [4, Section V.8].
Theorem 5: Regular conditional distribution exists if (Λ,L)(\Lambda, \mathcal{L})(Λ,L)﻿ is nice.
A generalization of the last theorem:
Theorem 6: Suppose (Λ,L)(\Lambda, \mathcal{L})(Λ,L)﻿ is a nice space, TTT﻿ and SSS﻿ are measurable mappings from Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ to Λ\LambdaΛ﻿, and G=σ(S).\mathcal{G} = \sigma(S).G=σ(S).﻿ Then there exists a function μ ⁣:Λ×L→[0,1]\mu \colon \Lambda \times \mathcal{L} \to [0,1]μ:Λ×L→[0,1]﻿ such that
for a.e. ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿, μ(S(ω),⋅)\mu(S(\omega), \cdot)μ(S(ω),⋅)﻿ is a probability measure on L\mathcal{L}L﻿, and
for each A∈LA \in \mathcal{L}A∈L﻿, μ(S(⋅),A)=P(T−1(A)∣G)\mu(S(\cdot), A) = \mathbb{P}(T^{-1}(A)\mid\mathcal{G})μ(S(⋅),A)=P(T−1(A)∣G)﻿ a.s..
It is instructive to prove Theorem 5 in the special case when (Λ,L)=(Rn,B(Rn)).(\Lambda, \mathcal{L}) = (\R^n, \mathcal{B}(\R^n)).(Λ,L)=(Rn,B(Rn)).﻿ The theorem and the proof is taken from [2].
Theorem 7: In the setting of Definition 4, let (Λ,L)=(Rn,B(Rn))(\Lambda, \mathcal{L}) = (\R^n, \mathcal{B}(\R^n))(Λ,L)=(Rn,B(Rn))﻿ and T=(T1,…,Tn) ⁣:Ω→Rn.T = (T_1, \ldots, T_n) \colon \Omega \to \R^n.T=(T1​,…,Tn​):Ω→Rn.﻿ Then there exists a regular conditional distribution for TTT﻿ given G.\mathcal{G}.G.﻿
Proof:
Let's recall the definition of an nnn﻿-dimensional distribution function on Rn\R^nRn﻿ (the Russian convention of left-continuous distribution function).
An nnn﻿-dimensional distribution function on Rn\R^nRn﻿ is a function F ⁣:Rn→[0,1]F \colon \R^n \to [0,1]F:Rn→[0,1]﻿ satisfying:
lim⁡xj→−∞F(x1,…,xn)=0,1≤j≤n(i)%\begin{align*} \lim_{x_j \to - \infty} F(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 0, \quad 1 \le j \le n \tag{i} %\end{align*}xj​→−∞lim​F(x1​,…,xn​)=0,1≤j≤n(i)
lim⁡xj→∞1≤j≤nF(x1,…,xn)=1(ii)\lim_{\substack{x_j \to \infty \\ 1 \le j \le n}} F(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = 1 \tag{ii}xj​→∞1≤j≤n​lim​F(x1​,…,xn​)=1(ii)
lim⁡yj↑xjF(x1,…,xj−1,yj,xj+1,…,xn)=F(x1,…,xj,…,xn),1≤j≤n(iii)\lim_{y_j \uparrow x_j} F(x_1, \ldots, x_{j-1}, y_j, x_{j+1}, \ldots, x_n) = F(x_1, \ldots, x_j, \ldots, x_n), \quad 1 \le j \le n \tag{iii}yj​↑xj​lim​F(x1​,…,xj−1​,yj​,xj+1​,…,xn​)=F(x1​,…,xj​,…,xn​),1≤j≤n(iii)
Δna,b:=F(b1,…,bn)−∑j=1nF(b1,…,bj−1,aj,bj+1,…,bn)+∑1≤j<k≤nF(b1,…,bj−1,aj,bj+1,…,bk−1,ak,bk+1,…,bn)−⋯(−1)nF(a1,…,an)≥0.(iv)\small\begin{align*}&\Delta_n^{a,b} := F(b_1, \ldots, b_n) - \sum_{j=1}^n F(b_1, \ldots, b_{j-1}, a_j, b_{j+1}, \ldots, b_n) \\ &+ \sum_{1 \le j < k \le n} F(b_1, \ldots, b_{j-1}, a_j, b_{j+1}, \ldots, b_{k-1}, a_k, b_{k+1}, \ldots, b_n) - \cdots (-1)^n F(a_1, \ldots, a_n) \\ &\ge 0. \tag{iv} \end{align*} ​Δna,b​:=F(b1​,…,bn​)−j=1∑n​F(b1​,…,bj−1​,aj​,bj+1​,…,bn​)+1≤j<k≤n∑​F(b1​,…,bj−1​,aj​,bj+1​,…,bk−1​,ak​,bk+1​,…,bn​)−⋯(−1)nF(a1​,…,an​)≥0.​(iv)
